name: Advanced Conditionals - Imagined Past
description: Use sophisticated conditional structures for hypothetical past situations
examples: Had I known, I would have acted differently
Were it not for his help, I would have failed

name: Participle Clauses Advanced
description: Use complex participle clauses for concise expression (perfect, passive)
examples: Having been warned, she proceeded cautiously
Being situated near the coast, it enjoys mild weather

name: Fronting for Emphasis
description: Use fronting of elements for emphasis and stylistic effect
examples: Rarely have I encountered such incompetence

name: Nominalization Advanced
description: Use advanced nominalization for academic and formal writing

name: Complex Passive Structures
description: Use complex passive structures (progressive, perfect, modal combinations)
examples: The work should have been finished

name: Subjunctive Advanced
description: Use subjunctive in all contexts (mandative, formulaic, hypothetical)
examples: It is imperative that he be present

name: Cleft Sentences Advanced
description: Use all types of cleft sentences for sophisticated emphasis (wh-clefts, there-clefts)
examples: The reason I came is that...

name: Extraposition
description: Use extraposition with 'it' for formal style
examples: It remains to be seen whether...

name: Hedging Advanced
description: Use sophisticated hedging devices for academic writing and cautious claims

name: Intensifying and Downtoning
description: Use intensifiers and downtoners with precision

name: Discourse Organization
description: Organize extended discourse with sophisticated structuring devices

name: Cohesion Sophisticated
description: Use sophisticated cohesive devices for academic and formal texts

name: Concession and Contrast Advanced
description: Express concession and contrast with sophisticated structures

name: Vocabulary Set - Specialized Academic
description: Master specialized academic vocabulary across disciplines
examples: paradigm, empirical, ubiquitous, inherent, comprehensive, substantial, contemporary, notion, framework

name: Vocabulary Set - Business Advanced
description: Master advanced business and economic vocabulary
examples: synergy, paradigm shift, scalability, divest, amortization, arbitrage, hedging, portfolio diversification

name: Metaphor and Figurative Language
description: Understand and use metaphors, similes, and figurative language

name: Irony and Sarcasm
description: Recognize, understand, and use irony and sarcasm appropriately

name: Register - Fine Distinctions
description: Make fine distinctions in register for subtle social and professional contexts
examples: Distinguish between formal, semi-formal, consultative, casual, intimate registers

name: Cultural References and Allusions
description: Understand and use cultural references and literary allusions

name: Collocations Expert
description: Use expert-level collocations naturally across contexts
examples: intrinsically linked, tentatively suggest, fundamentally flawed, inherently problematic, tacitly accepted

name: Euphemism and Dysphemism
description: Recognize and use euphemisms and dysphemisms appropriately

name: Semantic Precision
description: Choose words with precise semantic nuance for exact meaning
examples: affect vs effect, imply vs infer, allude vs elude, empathy vs sympathy, principle vs principal

name: Writing Academic Papers
description: Write academic papers with proper structure, citations, and academic voice (500+ words)
examples: Abstract, introduction with literature review, methodology, results, discussion, conclusion, references

name: Writing Critical Essays
description: Write critical essays analyzing and evaluating ideas, texts, or arguments
examples: Critical analysis, evaluation of arguments, synthesis of sources, original perspective

name: Writing - Synthesis
description: Synthesize information from multiple sources into coherent argument
examples: Integrate multiple sources, identify patterns, create original argument from synthesis

name: Writing - Style Variations
description: Write in different styles for different purposes (narrative, descriptive, expository, persuasive)
examples: Adapt style for creative, academic, journalistic, technical writing

name: Writing - Audience Awareness
description: Adapt writing precisely for specific audiences and purposes
examples: Expert vs lay audience, academic vs general public, professional vs casual

name: Speaking - Fluent and Spontaneous
description: Speak fluently and spontaneously on any topic without preparation
examples: Effortless expression, natural flow, minimal hesitation on complex topics

name: Speaking - Complex Ideas
description: Express complex ideas clearly and precisely with sophisticated language
examples: Articulate abstract concepts, philosophical ideas, theoretical frameworks clearly

name: Speaking - Professional Presentations
description: Deliver professional presentations with confidence, clarity, and engagement
examples: Handle Q&A, engage audience, use rhetorical devices, manage time effectively

name: Pronunciation - Native-like Features
description: Produce native-like pronunciation features (schwa, flapping, glottalization)

name: Pronunciation - Prosody Expert
description: Use expert-level prosody (stress, rhythm, intonation) for nuanced meaning
examples: Use prosody to convey attitude, emotion, emphasis, irony

name: Reading - Complex Texts
description: Read and understand highly complex texts (philosophy, law, academic papers)
examples: Philosophy papers, legal documents, dense academic prose, literary texts

name: Reading - Critical Analysis
description: Critically analyze texts for argument structure, evidence, bias, assumptions
examples: Identify logical fallacies, evaluate evidence quality, detect hidden assumptions

name: Reading - Synthesizing Sources
description: Synthesize information and perspectives from multiple complex sources
examples: Compare perspectives across sources, identify patterns, create synthesis

name: Listening - Nuanced Meaning
description: Understand subtle nuances, implications, and undertones in speech
examples: Detect subtle irony, understand implications, recognize hedging, identify tone shifts

name: Listening - Academic Discourse
description: Understand complex academic discourse, lectures, seminars on specialized topics
examples: Follow complex arguments, understand specialized terminology, identify thesis and support

name: Listening - Accents and Varieties
description: Understand different accents and varieties of English effortlessly
examples: British, American, Australian, Indian, South African accents and dialects

name: Strategic Competence Advanced
description: Use advanced communication strategies flexibly and effectively
examples: Reformulate seamlessly, use sophisticated circumlocution, repair effectively

name: Autonomy in Learning
description: Learn independently, identify gaps, seek resources, self-correct effectively
examples: Self-assess, use dictionaries effectively, identify learning needs, seek feedback

name: Pragmatic Competence
description: Use language appropriately for social and cultural contexts with precision
examples: Politeness strategies, indirect speech acts, conversational implicature, context-appropriate language

name: Discourse Management
description: Manage extended discourse effectively (topic development, turn management, coherence)
examples: Develop topics, manage turns smoothly, maintain coherence across extended discourse

name: Intercultural Competence
description: Navigate intercultural communication with awareness of cultural differences
examples: Cultural awareness, adapt communication style, avoid misunderstandings, show cultural sensitivity

name: Metalinguistic Awareness
description: Reflect on and discuss language itself (grammar, style, usage, variation)
examples: Discuss grammar rules, analyze style choices, comment on language change, evaluate usage
